importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the lawsuit filing and the key development in the political dispute over the swearing-in of Representative Adelita Grijalva.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeframe of the election of Adelita Grijalva, which occurred in late September 2025, is central to the dispute over whether the House of Representatives can delay seating her due to a government shutdown.

keyTakeAways: Arizona’s attorney general has sued the U.S. House of Representatives over Speaker Mike Johnson’s refusal to swear in newly elected Democrat Representative Adelita Grijalva.

The lawsuit claims that the Constitution requires all duly elected members to be sworn in, regardless of Speaker’s discretion, and that the Speaker lacks constitutional authority to delay the swearing-in process.

Speaker Mike Johnson justifies his delay by citing a precedent from Nancy Pelosi, where she deferred swearing-in members after recess, but this precedent does not apply when the election occurs during a session’s absence.
The lawsuit alleges that Johnson is using the delay to avoid a petition on Jeffrey Epstein records and to strengthen his position in budget negotiations.
Grijalva has not spoken to Johnson in 28 days since her election and is attempting to schedule a meeting to resolve the standoff.
The case raises constitutional questions about the Speaker's authority to delay seating elected members and whether such a delay violates the principle of representation.
The lawsuit seeks a federal court order allowing a qualified individual to administer the oath of office to Grijalva if Johnson refuses to do so.

namedEntities.name: Arizona
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Arizona is the state that elected Representative Adelita Grijalva, and the state's attorney general is taking legal action to protect the rights of its newly elected congresswoman, asserting that constitutional principles must be upheld for fair representation.

namedEntities.name: Adelita Grijalva
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A member of the U.S. House of Representatives
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Grijalva is the newly elected Democrat congresswoman from Arizona whose swearing-in has been delayed, making her central to the political and legal dispute over constitutional rights and representation.

namedEntities.name: Mike Johnson
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Speaker of the U.S. House of Representatives
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Johnson is the key political figure who refused to swear in Grijalva, citing precedent and procedural rules, and whose actions are at the center of the legal and political conflict over the legitimacy and timing of congressional appointments.

namedEntities.name: Nancy Pelosi
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former Speaker of the U.S. House of Representatives
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Pelosi is referenced as a precedent for delaying swearing-in after a recess, which Mike Johnson cites to justify his own delay, though the lawsuit disputes the relevance of that precedent in this context.

namedEntities.name: Jeffrey Epstein
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The lawsuit alleges that Johnson’s delay is politically motivated to avoid a House petition to release records related to Epstein, highlighting a potential conflict between political strategy and constitutional obligations.

namedEntities.name: U.S. House of Representatives
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The House is the institution where the swearing-in of Grijalva is contested, and its rules and procedures are central to the constitutional and political debate over representation and procedural authority.

namedEntities.name: Kris Mayes
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Mayes is the lead legal figure filing the lawsuit, representing Arizona’s interest in ensuring that a duly elected representative is seated promptly under constitutional standards.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Arizona’s attorney general, Kris Mayes, has filed a lawsuit against the U.S. House of Representatives, challenging Speaker Mike Johnson’s refusal to swear in newly elected Democrat Representative Adelita Grijalva from Arizona. The lawsuit argues that the Constitution requires all duly elected members to be seated, and that Johnson’s delay—citing a precedent from Nancy Pelosi—violates constitutional principles and undermines democratic representation. The suit alleges that Johnson’s actions are politically motivated, aimed at avoiding a petition on Jeffrey Epstein records and strengthening his leverage in budget negotiations. Grijalva, who won her election in late September 2025, has not spoken to Johnson in 28 days and is attempting to meet with him to resolve the situation. The lawsuit seeks a federal court order allowing a qualified person to administer the oath if Johnson continues to delay. The case raises broader constitutional questions about the Speaker’s authority in seating members and the balance between political strategy and democratic accountability.
title: Arizona Sues Over Mike Johnson’s Refusal to Swear In Democrats’ Newest Congresswoman
